comment: Took him during Spring 2022. I struggled in his course for sure. Luckily was saved by his heavy test curves by the end of the semester that pulled my grade to a B. Graded by a few things, test heavy & had to be taken in person, & super lecture heavy. Be cautious if you take him.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I loved Professor Albrecht! His class is graded from 3 tests worth 30% each, and 10% for homework (there's only hw twice during the semester). You have to go to class to succeed in this class, the tests are difficult, but there is a HUGE curve, and if you prepare well, you should get 100+ on each test!

His class is incredibly difficult even if you put the work in. I went to class everyday and attended office hours yet NONE of the information made sense because he talks and teaches in circles. Overall, he is very unclear, even when you ask him a pointed question you will still be confused, at least I was. He does offer very generous curves though!
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Not to be harsh but this guy is a horrible professor. He seems like a nice guy but he just talks circles. I didn't learn anything from his class. He's very hard to follow and he trips himself up when talking. He had a really hard time answering any student questions. He gives practice tests similar to exams which is the only reason I did well.

comment: Brian is super devoted to econ and has passionate lectures. Graded by 2 things, 3 exams worth 30% and 6 mini hw things worth 10%. No final exam. Exams are difficult but there is HEAVY curves applied. No attendance is required. If you miss a test the subsequent one is worth double. Not difficult to pass but to get a high grade prepare to put in work

Grade consists of three tests and two homework assignments only worth 10%. The tests are in person and written so you need to be able to explain yourself. His lectures are long and can get confusing. He is a lenient grader and heavily curves his tests.

comment: As a dual enrollment student, I was only taking this class for credit. I found his class very easy, the 3 exams cover 90% of the final grade, and 10% is allotted to homework. He gives huge curves which makes it easy to get an A on each exam if you prepare well. He is always available outside class and make sure to exam review sessions!!!

comment: Difficult subject overall. In addition, the lectures are not the best. However, he does make up for it with generous grading. comment: Unless you find being stressed out fun and exciting, dont take his class. His lectures are boring and hard to follow because he talks in circles. His lecture notes arent any better. There are 3 exams (based off his lecture notes) and very little homework.

He teaches in a lecture heavy style but goes off on multiple tangents through out the class. He is a good guy but horrible teacher. Only graded by a few tests and very little homework assignments. comment: He does paper testing. It is more conceptual than anything. If you cant teach yourself this subject do not take him.

After the first week, this guy was MIA. Every single lecture video was someone else teaching. Quizzes & exams were automatically graded, & the 4 assignments he actually had to grade weren't graded until the day before final course grades were due, & they were turned in throughout the semester. Never answered my email. M. Doral ran the class for him

Prof. Albrecht was okay. Course consisted of 13 quizzes where he dropped the lowest 3, 4 extra credit opportunities where he counted the highest 2, a mid-term, and a final. His lectures were boring, but he made up for that by making the quizzes and tests easy, only because they were open note. Not sure if he's like this without covid being a thing.

comment: He is new to KSU, so be aware of any difficulties on D2L. Graded by quizzes, mid term and exam, with the 2 lowest quizzes dropped. Can seem clumsy, so be patient. At least 1 quiz each week with 5 questions each - so be prepared to get an 80 if you miss just one!

comment: I believe it's the professor's first year at KSU. All online. We had weekly quizzes that were 5 questions only. We had a midterm and a final that was also super easy. We had 2 discussions and short essays that were extra credit. There was no lockdown browser. I am not sure if things would be different if in-person. I do not want to mislead anyone.
